=== Grid parity ===
{{main|Grid parity}}
Solar generating stations have become progressively cheaper in recent years, and this trend is expected to continue.<ref>{{cite news|author=Aaron|title=Solar panels to keep getting cheaper|url=http://www.evoenergy.co.uk/blog/12483/solar-panels-to-keep-getting-cheaper/|accessdate=13 January 2015|newspaper=Evo Energy|date=23 November 2012}}</ref> Meanwhile, traditional electricity generation is becoming progressively more expensive.<ref>{{cite news|last=Jago|first=Simon|title=Prices going one way|url=http://www.energylivenews.com/2013/03/06/steve-armitage-of-gazprom-energy-talks-bills-and-efficiency/|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=Energy Live News|date=6 March 2013}}</ref> These trends are expected to lead to a crossover point when the levelised cost of energy from solar parks, historically more expensive, matches the cost of traditional electricity generation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Burkart|first=Karl|title=5 breakthroughs that will make solar power cheaper than coal|url=http://www.mnn.com/green-tech/research-innovations/blogs/5-breakthroughs-that-will-make-solar-power-cheaper-than-coal|publisher=Mother Nature Network|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> This point is commonly referred to as grid parity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Spross|first=Jeff|title=Solar Report Stunner: Unsubsidized ‘Grid Parity Has Been Reached In India’, Italy–With More Countries Coming in 2014|url=http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2013/03/03/1664481/solar-report-stunner-unsubsidized-grid-parity-has-been-reached-in-india-italy-with-more-countries-coming-in-2014/?mob|publisher=Climate Progress|accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref>
For merchant solar power stations, where the electricity is being sold into the electricity transmission network, the levelised cost of solar energy will need to match the wholesale electricity price. This point is sometimes called 'wholesale grid parity' or 'busbar parity'.<ref name=UN-Energy-2012>{{cite report |url=http://www.un-energy.org/stories/2498-re-considering-the-economics-of-photovoltaic-power |title=Re-considering the economics of photovoltaic power |author=Morgan Baziliana |display-authors=etal |work=UN-Energy |publisher=United Nations |date=17 May 2012 |accessdate=20 November 2012 |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160516014242/http://www.un-energy.org/stories/2498-re-considering-the-economics-of-photovoltaic-power# |archivedate=16 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
Some photovoltaic systems, such as rooftop installations, can supply power directly to an electricity user. In these cases, the installation can be competitive when the output cost matches the price at which the user pays for his electricity consumption. This situation is sometimes called 'retail grid parity', 'socket parity' or 'dynamic grid parity'.<ref name=EPIA>{{cite web|title=Solar Photovoltaics competing in the energy sector – On the road to competitiveness|url=http://www.epia.org/index.php?eID=tx_nawsecuredl&u=0&file=fileadmin/EPIA_docs/publications/epia/Competing_Full_Report.pdf&t=1344960599&hash=b6962eb52b3e5ee0d9c159950995362c|publisher=EPIA|accessdate=30 August 2012}}</ref> Research carried out by [[UN-Energy]] in 2012 suggests areas of sunny countries with high electricity prices, such as Italy, Spain and Australia, and areas using diesel generators, have reached retail grid parity.<ref name=UN-Energy-2012/>
=== Incentive mechanisms ===
Because the point of grid parity has not yet been reached in many parts of the world, solar generating stations need some form of financial incentive to compete for the supply of electricity.<ref>{{cite web|last=Wolfe|first=Philip|title=Priorities for low carbon transition|url=http://politicsofclimatechange.wordpress.com/priorities-for-low-carbon-transition/philip-wolfe/|work=The politics of Climate Change|publisher=The Policy Network|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> Many legislatures around the world have introduced such incentives to support the deployment of solar power stations.<ref>{{cite web|title=Taxes and Incentives for renewable energy|url=http://www.kpmg.com/Global/en/IssuesAndInsights/ArticlesPublications/Documents/taxes-incentives-renewable-energy-2012.pdf|publisher=KPMG|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
==== Feed-in tariffs ====
{{main|Feed-in tariff}}
Feed-in tariffs are designated prices which must be paid by utility companies for each kilowatt hour of renewable electricity produced by qualifying generators and fed into the grid.<ref>{{cite web|title=Policymaker's Guide to Feed-in Tariff Policy Design|url=http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy10osti/448|publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory|accessdate=22 April 2013}} Couture, T., Cory, K., Kreycik, C., Williams, E., (2010). National Renewable Energy Laboratory, U.S. Dept. of Energy</ref> These tariffs normally represent a premium on wholesale electricity prices and offer a guaranteed revenue stream to help the power producer finance the project.<ref>{{cite web|title=What are Feed-in Tariffs|url=http://www.fitariffs.co.uk/FITs/|publisher=Feed-in Tariffs Limited|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
==== Renewable portfolio standards and supplier obligations ====
{{main|Renewable portfolio standard}}
These standards are obligations on utility companies to source a proportion of their electricity from renewable generators.<ref>{{cite web|title=Race to the Top: The Expanding Role of U.S. State Renewable Portfolio Standards|url=http://www.c2es.org/docUploads/RPSReportFin|publisher=University of Michigan|accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref> In most cases, they do not prescribe which technology should be used and the utility is free to select the most appropriate renewable sources.<ref>{{cite web|title=Investment in electricity generation - the role of costs, incentives and risks|url=http://seg.fsu.edu/Library/Investment%20in%20Electricity%20Generation_%20The%20Role%20of%20Costs,%20Incentives,%20and%20Risks.pdf|publisher=UK Energy Research Centre|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
There are some exceptions where solar technologies are allocated a proportion of the RPS in what is sometimes referred to as a 'solar set aside'.<ref>{{cite web|title=Solar Carve-Outs in Renewables Portfolio Standards|url=http://www.dsireusa.org/solar/solarpolicyguide/?id=21|publisher=Dsire Solar|accessdate=30 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121021172843/http://www.dsireusa.org/solar/solarpolicyguide/?id=21|archivedate=21 October 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==== Loan guarantees and other capital incentives ====
{{main|Loan guarantee}}
Some countries and states adopt less targeted financial incentives, available for a wide range of infrastructure investment, such as the US Department of Energy loan guarantee scheme,<ref>{{cite web|title=Innovative Technology Loan Guarantee Program|url=http://www.doe.gov/sites/prod/files/edg/recovery/documents/Innovative__Technology_Loan_Guarantee_Program.pdf|publisher=US DOE Loan Guarantee Program Office (LGPO)|accessdate=21 February 2012}}</ref> which stimulated a number of investments in the solar power plant in 2010 and 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Review: DOE’s Loan Guarantee Program Has Worked, Can Be Better|url=http://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/does-loan-guarantee-program-has-worked-can-be-better-independent-review|publisher=GreenTech Media|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
==== Tax credits and other fiscal incentives ====
{{main|Tax credit}}
Another form of indirect incentive which has been used to stimulate investment in solar power plant was tax credits available to investors. In some cases the credits were linked to the energy produced by the installations, such as the Production Tax Credits.<ref>{{cite web|title=Production Tax Credit for Renewable Energy|url=http://www.ucsusa.org/clean_energy/smart-energy-solutions/increase-renewables/production-tax-credit-for.html|publisher=Union of Concerned Scientists|accessdate=30 August 2012}}</ref> In other cases the credits were related to the capital investment such as the Investment Tax Credits<ref>{{cite web|title=Business Energy Investment Tax Credit (ITC)|url=http://www.doe.gov/savings/business-energy-investment-tax-credit-itc|publisher=US Department of Energy|accessdate=21 February 2012}}</ref>
==== International, national and regional programmes ====
In addition to free market commercial incentives, some countries and regions have specific programs to support the deployment of solar energy installations.
The [[European Union]]'s [[Renewables Directive]]<ref>{{cite web|work=Renewables Directive|url=http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2009:140:0016:0062:EN:PDF|title=Directive 2009/28/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council|publisher=European Commission}}</ref> sets targets for increasing levels of deployment of renewable energy in all member states. Each has been required to develop a [[National Renewable Energy Action Plan]] showing how these targets would be met, and many of these have specific support measures for solar energy deployment.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ragwitz|first=Mario|display-authors=etal|title=Assessment of National Renewable Energy Action Plans|url=http://www.repap2020.eu/fileadmin/user_upload/Roadmaps/D115-Assessment_of_NREAPs__REPAP_report_-_final_edition_.pdf|work=REPAP 2020|publisher=Fraunhofer Institut|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> The directive also allows states to develop projects outside their national boundaries, and this may lead to bilateral programs such as the Helios project.<ref>{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Andrew|title=Project Helios: A brighter future for Greece?|url=http://www.solarnovus.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=3790:project-helios-a-brighter-future-for-greece&catid=38:application-tech-features&Itemid=246|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=Solar Novus Today|date=3 November 2011}}</ref>
The [[Clean Development Mechanism]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Clean Development Mechanism (CDM)|url=http://unfccc.int/kyoto_protocol/mechanisms/clean_development_mechanism/items/2718.php|publisher=UNFCCC|accessdate=30 December 2012}}</ref> of the [[UNFCCC]] is an international programme under which solar generating stations in certain qualifying countries can be supported.<ref>{{cite web|title=CDM projects grouped in types|url=http://www.cdmpipeline.org/cdm-projects-type.htm#2|publisher=UNEP Risø Centre|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
Additionally many other countries have specific solar energy development programmes. Some examples are [[India]]'s [[Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission|JNNSM]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Ministry of New and Renewable Energy|title=The Jawaharlal Nehru National Solar Mission|url=http://www.mnre.gov.in/solar-mission/jnnsm/introduction-2/|work=Scheme documents|publisher=Government of India|accessdate=30 December 2012}}</ref> the Flagship Program in [[Australia]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Department for Resources, Energy and Tourism|title=Solar Flagships Program Open for Business|url=http://minister.ret.gov.au/mediacentre/mediareleases/pages/solarflagshipsprogramopenforbusiness.aspx|accessdate=30 December 2012|newspaper=Government of Australia|date=11 Dec 2009}}</ref> and similar projects in [[South Africa]]<ref>{{cite news|title=South Africa: Renewable Energy Programme to Bring R47 Billion in Investment|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201210291349.html|accessdate=30 December 2012|newspaper=allAfrica.com|date=29 Oct 2012}}</ref> and [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Solar Energy|url=http://energy.gov.il/English/Subjects/RenewableEnergy/Pages/GxmsMniRenewableEnergySolarEnergy.aspx|publisher=Ministry of Energy and Water Resources|accessdate=30 December 2012}}</ref>
=== Financial performance ===
The financial performance of the solar power plant is a function of its income and its costs.<ref name=Wolfe_book />
The electrical output of a solar park will be related to the solar radiation, the capacity of the plant and its performance ratio.<ref name=PerfRatio /> The income derived from this electrical output will come primarily from the sale of the electricity,<ref>{{cite web|title=Investment in Solar Parks|url=http://www.solar-partner.com/en/investment-in-solar-parks.html|publisher=Solar Partner|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> and any incentive payments such as those under Feed-in Tariffs or other support mechanisms.<ref>{{cite web|title=Community ownership|url=http://www.westmillsolar.coop/faq.asp|work=FAQs|publisher=Westmill Solar Cooperative|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref>
Electricity prices may vary at different times of day, giving a higher price at times of high demand.<ref>{{cite web|title=What are time-of-use rates and how do they work?|url=http://www.pge.com/mybusiness/energysavingsrebates/timevaryingpricing/timeofusepricing/|publisher=Pacific Gas and Electric|accessdate=7 March 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202100847/http://www.pge.com/mybusiness/energysavingsrebates/timevaryingpricing/timeofusepricing/#|archive-date=2 February 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> This may influence the design of the plant to increase its output at such times.<ref>{{cite web|title=Optimum Orientation of Solar Panels for Time-of-Use Rates|url=http://www.macslab.com/optsolarpg|publisher=Macs Lab|accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref>
The dominant costs of solar power plants are the capital cost, and therefore any associated financing and depreciation.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Optimum Financing Structure|url=http://www.greenrhinoenergy.com/finance/renewable/which_structure.php|publisher=Green Rhino Energy|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> Though operating costs are typically relatively low, especially as no fuel is required,<ref name=low_maintenance /> most operators will want to ensure that adequate operation and maintenance cover<ref name=OandM /> is available to maximise the availability of the plant and thereby optimise the income to cost ratio.<ref>{{cite news|last=Belfiore|first=Francesco|title=Optimizing PV Plant O&M Requires Focus on the Project Lifecycle|url=http://www.renewableenergyworld.com/rea/news/article/2013/01/optimizing-pv-plant-o-m-requires-focus-on-the-project-lifecycle|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=Renewable Energy World}}</ref>
== Geography ==
{{main|Solar power by country|Growth of photovoltaics}}
The first places to reach grid parity were those with high traditional electricity prices and high levels of solar radiation.<ref name=Statistics>{{cite web|title=Statistics about selected locations for utility-scale solar parks|url=http://www.wiki-solar.org/analysis/index.html|publisher=Wiki-Solar|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> Currently, more capacity is being installed in the [[Rooftop photovoltaic power station|rooftop]] than in the utility-scale segment. However, the worldwide distribution of solar parks is expected to change as different regions achieve grid parity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Solar Photovoltaics competing in the energy sector – On the road to competitiveness|url=http://www.epia.org/index.php?eID=tx_nawsecuredl&u=0&file=/uploads/tx_epiapublications/Competing_Full_Report.pdf&t=1365998776&hash=2610e73e375d255b587ac517aa2d9eb9d6789664|publisher=European Photovoltaic Industry Association|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref> This transition also includes a shift from rooftop towards utility-scale plants, since the focus of new PV deployment has changed from Europe towards the ''Sunbelt markets'' where ground-mounted PV systems are favored.<ref name=epia-2014 />{{rp|43}}
Because of the economic background, large-scale systems are presently distributed where the support regimes have been the most consistent, or the most advantageous.<ref>{{cite web| title=Renewable Power, Policy, and the Cost of Capital |url=http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/handle/2027.42/50488/070419%20RPPCC%20FIN |publisher=UNEP/BASE Sustainable Energy Finance Initiative |accessdate=22 April 2013}} Retrieved 13 April 2013</ref> Total capacity of worldwide PV plants above 4 MW<sub>AC</sub> was assessed by [[Wiki-Solar]] as 36 GW in c. 2,300 installations at the end of 2014<ref>{{cite web|title=Utility-scale solar breaks all records in 2014 to reach 36 GW|url=http://wiki-solar.org/library/public/150305_Utility-solar_2014_figures_set%20multiple_records.pdf|website=wiki-solar.org|publisher=Wiki-Solar|ref=WS2014}}</ref> and represents about 25 percent of total global PV capacity of 139 GW.<ref name=epia-2014> {{cite web |title = Global Market Outlook for Photovoltaics 2014-2018 |url = http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf |website = www.epia.org |publisher = EPIA - European Photovoltaic Industry Association |accessdate = 12 June 2014 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6QGSvAF7w?url=http://www.epia.org/fileadmin/user_upload/Publications/EPIA_Global_Market_Outlook_for_Photovoltaics_2014-2018_-_Medium_Res.pdf |archivedate = 12 June 2014 |deadurl = yes |df = dmy-all }}</ref>{{rp|17}} The countries which had the most capacity, in descending order, were the [[Solar power in the United States|United States]], [[Solar power in China|China]], [[Solar power in Germany|Germany]], [[Solar power in India|India]], [[Solar power in the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]], [[Solar power in Spain|Spain]], [[Solar power in Italy|Italy]], [[Solar power in Canada|Canada]] and [[Solar power in South Africa|South Africa]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Deployment of utility-scale solar parks - by country|url=http://wiki-solar.org/region/countries/index.html|publisher=Wiki-Solar.org|accessdate=27 February 2014}}</ref> Activities in the key markets are reviewed individually below.
=== China ===
{{main|Solar power in China}}
China was reported in early 2013 to have overtaken Germany as the nation with the most utility-scale solar capacity.<ref name=Capacity_2013>{{cite news|last=Hill|first=Joshua|title=Giant Solar Farm Capacity Doubling Inside 12 Months Breaking 12 GW|url=http://cleantechnica.com/2013/02/22/giant-solar-farms-capacity-doubling-inside-12-months-breaking-12-gw/|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=Clean Technica|date=22 February 2013}}</ref> Much of this has been supported by the [[Clean Development Mechanism]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Project search|url=http://cdm.unfccc.int/Projects/projsearch.html|work=CDM: Project activities|publisher=UNFCCC|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> The distribution of power plants around the country is quite broad, with the highest concentration in the Gobi desert<ref name=China_map /> and connected to the Northwest China Power Grid.<ref>{{cite web|title=Northwest China Grid Company Limited|url=http://www.nw.sgcc.com.cn/E-company/coma|publisher=Northwest China Grid Company Limited|accessdate=22 April 2013}}</ref>
=== Germany ===
{{main|Solar power in Germany}}
The first multi-megawatt plant in Europe was the 4.2 MW community-owned project at Hemau, commissioned in 2003.<ref name=Hemau>{{cite web|title=In Hemau liefert der weltweit größte Solarpark umweltfreundlichen Strom aus der Sonne|url=http://www.hemau.de/index.asp?NAVIID=%7B21B64141-C02C-4194-8A02-7D54CA2AB16F%7D|publisher=Stadt Hemau|language =German|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref> But it was the revisions to the German feed-in tariffs in 2004,<ref name=EEG2004 /> which gave the strongest impetus to the establishment of utility-scale solar power plants.<ref>{{cite web|title=Best of Both Worlds: What if German installation costs were combined with the best solar resources?|url=https://financere.nrel.gov/finance/content/germany-solar-feed-in-tariff-FIT-insolation-resource-comp|publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory|accessdate=22 April 2013}} Retrieved 13 April 2013</ref> The first to be completed under this programme was the Leipziger Land solar park developed by Geosol.<ref name=Leipziger_Land>{{cite web|title=Leipziger Land project|url=http://www.geosol.de/sites/default/files/references/GERMANY%20REFERENCE%20Leipziger%20Land%20-%20EN.pdf|publisher=Geosol|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref> Several dozen plants were built between 2004 and 2011, several of which were at the time the [[#Noteworthy solar parks|largest in the world]]. The [[German Renewable Energy Act|EEG]], the law which establishes Germany’s feed-in tariffs, provides the legislative basis not just for the compensation levels, but other regulatory factors, such as priority access to the grid.<ref name=Priority_access /> The law was amended in 2010 to restrict the use of agricultural land,<ref>{{cite news|last=Olson|first=Syanne|title=IBC Solar completes grid connection for 13.8MW German solar park|url=http://www.pv-tech.org/news/ibc_solar_completes_grid_connection_for_13.8mw_german_solar_park|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=PV-Tech|date=14 January 2011}}</ref> since which time most solar parks have been built on so-called ‘development land’, such as former military sites.<ref name=Neuhardenberg /> Partly for this reason, the geographic distribution of photovoltaic power plants in Germany<ref name=Wiki-Germany /> is biased towards the former Eastern Germany.<ref>{{cite news|title=Eastern Germany's sunny future |work=Michael Dumiak |url=http://archive.fortune.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2007/05/28/100049624/index.htm |publisher=Fortune magazine |date=22 May 2007|accessdate=15 January 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=German PV Funding Up In The Air Again|url=http://www.solarbuzz.com/resources/analyst-insights/german-pv-funding-air|publisher=SolarBuzz|accessdate=22 April 2013}} Retrieved 13 April 2013</ref> As of February 2012, Germany had 1.1 million photovoltaic power plants (most are small kW roof mounted).<ref>{{cite web|title=Goodnight Sunshine|url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/project_syndicate/2012/02/why_germany_is_phasing_out_its_solar_power_subsidies|publisher=Slate|accessdate=22 April 2013}} Retrieved 13 April 2013</ref>
=== India ===
{{main|Solar power in India}}
India has been rising up the leading nations for the installation of utility-scale solar capacity. The [[Charanka Solar Park]] in [[Gujarat]] was opened officially in April 2012<ref>{{cite news|title=Gujarat Solar Park Inauguration at Charanka, Gujarat|url=http://www.indiansolarsummit.com/gujarat-solar-park-inauguration-at-charanka-gujarat/|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=Indian Solar Summit|date=19 April 2012}}</ref> and was at the time the [[#Noteworthy solar parks|largest group of solar power plants]] in the world.
Geographically the states with the largest installed capacity are [[Telangana]], [[Rajasthan]] and [[Andhra Pradesh]] with over 2 [[Gigawatt|GW]] of installed solar power capacity each<ref name=capa>{{cite web |url=http://mnre.gov.in/file-manager/UserFiles/grid-connected-solar-power-project-installed-capacity.pdf|title=State wise installed solar power capacity |publisher=Ministry of New and Renewable Energy, Govt. of India |date= 31 October 2017 |accessdate=24 November 2017}}</ref>. Rajasthan and Gujarat share the [[Thar Desert]], along with Pakistan. In September 2018 Acme Solar announced that it had commissioned India's cheapest solar power plant, the 200 [[megawatt|MW]] Rajasthan Bhadla solar power park <ref>{{cite news|title=Acme Solar Commissions India’s Cheapest Solar Power Plant|url=https://cleantechnica.com/2018/09/24/acme-solar-commissions-indias-cheapest-solar-power-plant/|accessdate=29 September 2018}}</ref>.
=== Italy ===
{{main|Solar power in Italy}}
Italy has a very large number of photovoltaic power plants, the largest of which is the 84 MW [[Montalto di Castro Photovoltaic Power Station|Montalto di Castro project]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Top 10 Solar PV Power Plants|url=http://www.interpv.net/market/market_view.asp?idx=570&part_c|publisher=InterPV|accessdate=22 April 2013}} Retrieved 13 April 2013</ref>
===Jordan=== By the end of 2017, it was reported that more than 732 MW of solar energy projects had been completed, which contributed to 7% of Jordan's electricity.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pp-magazine.com/2018/04/27/103-mw-solar-plant-comes-online-in-jordan/|title=103 MW solar plant comes online in Jordan|accessdate=28 April 2018|date=26 April 2018|work=PV magazine}}</ref> After having initially set the percentage of renewable energy Jordan aimed to generate by 2020 at 10%, the government announced in 2018 that it sought to beat that figure and aim for 20%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-23/jordan-eyes-power-storage-as-next-step-in-green-energy-drive|title=Jordan Eyes Power Storage as Next Step in Green Energy Drive|author=Brian Parkin|accessdate=23 April 2018|date=23 April 2018|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> A report by pv magazine described Jordan as the "Middle East’s solar powerhouse".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pv-magazine.com/2018/01/06/solars-new-fertile-crescent/|title=Solar’s new fertile crescent|accessdate=16 January 2018|date=6 January 2018|work=pv magazine}}</ref>
=== Spain ===
{{main|Solar power in Spain}}
The majority of the deployment of solar power stations in Spain to date occurred during the boom market of 2007-8.<ref>{{cite news|title=Solar Industry Learns Lessons in Spanish Sun|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/03/09/business/energy-environment/09solar.html?_r=0|accessdate=7 March 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=8 March 2010|first=Elisabeth|last=Rosenthal}}</ref> The stations are well distributed around the country, with some concentration in [[Extremadura]], [[Castile-La Mancha]] and [[Murcia]].<ref name=Spain_map />
=== United Kingdom ===
{{main|Solar power in the United Kingdom}}
The introduction of [[Feed-in tariffs in the United Kingdom]] in 2010 stimulated the first wave of utility-scale projects,<ref name=WolfeWare>{{cite web|title=Solar parks in the UK|url=http://wolfeware.com/solar/history.html#UK|publisher=WolfeWare|accessdate=13 April 2013}}</ref> with c. 20 plants being completed<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.solarpowerportal.co.uk/editors_blog/just_how_many_solar_projects_beat_the_fast_track_review_5478| work=Solar Power Portal | first=Emma | last=Hughes | title=Updated: Just how many solar projects beat the fast-track review? | date=3 August 2011 | accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref> before tariffs were reduced on 1 August 2011 following the 'Fast Track Review'.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.greenbang.com/feed-in-tariff-cut-shocks-uk-pv-market_17123.html | work=greenbang.com | title=Feed-in tariff cut shocks UK PV market | date=28 March 2011 | accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref> A second wave of installations was undertaken under the UK's [[Renewables Obligation]], with the total number of plants connected by the end of March 2013 reaching 86.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.wiki-solar.org/library/public/130606_UK_is_Europes_top_market_Wiki-Solar.pdf | work=[[Wiki-Solar]] | title=UK tops Europe’s utility-scale solar market for 2013 | date=6 June 2013 | accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref> This is reported to have made the UK Europe's best market in the first quarter of 2013.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.photon.info/photon_news_detail_en.photon?id=77416| work=Photon International | title=UK becomes Europe's top utility-scale solar market | date=7 June 2013 | accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref>
UK projects were originally concentrated in the South West, but have more recently spread across the South of England and into East Anglia and the Midlands.<ref name=UK_map>{{cite web|title=Solar parks map - United Kingdom|url=http://www.wiki-solar.org/map/country/index.html?United_Kingdom?u-uN-GB|publisher=Wiki-Solar|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> The first solar park in Wales came on stream in 2011 at [[Rhoshill, Pembrokeshire|Rhosygilwen]], north [[Pembrokeshire]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC|title=Wales' first solar park powers up in Pembrokeshire|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-14073447|date=8 July 2011|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> As of June 2014 there were 18 schemes generating more than 5 MW and 34 in planning or construction in Wales.<ref>{{cite news|publisher=BBC|title=Solar parks: Large scale schemes 'to double' in Wales|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-28008406|date=25 June 2014|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref>
=== United States ===
{{main|Solar power in the United States}}
The US deployment of photovoltaic power stations is largely concentrated in southwestern states.<ref name=USA_map /> The Renewable Portfolio Standards in California<ref>{{cite web|title=California Renewables Portfolio Standard (RPS)|url=http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/PUC/energy/Renewables/index.htm|publisher=California Public Utilities Commission|accessdate=7 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130307050124/http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/PUC/energy/Renewables/index.htm|archivedate=7 March 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and surrounding states<ref>{{cite web|title=Nevada Energy Portfolio Standard|url=http://www.dsireusa.org/incentives/incentive.cfm?Incentive_Code=NV01R|work=Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency|publisher=US Department of Energy|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Arizona Energy Portfolio Standard|url=http://www.dsireusa.org/incentives/incentive.cfm?Incentive_Code=AZ03R|work=Database of State Incentives for Renewables & Efficiency|publisher=US Department of Energy|accessdate=7 March 2013}}</ref> provide a particular incentive. The volume of projects under construction in early 2013 has led to the forecast that the US will become the leading market.<ref name=Capacity_2013 />

'''Piezomagnetism''' is a phenomenon observed in some [[antiferromagnetic]] crystals. It is characterised by a [[linear]] coupling between the system's magnetic polarisation and [[Strain (materials science)|mechanical strain]]. In a piezomagnetic, one may induce a spontaneous [[magnetic moment]] by applying physical stress, or a physical deformation by applying a [[magnetic field]].
Piezomagnetism differs from the related property of [[magnetostriction]]; if an applied magnetic field is reversed in direction, the strain produced changes signs. Additionally, a non-zero piezomagnetic moment can be produced by mechanical strain ''alone'', at zero field - this is not true of magnetostriction.<ref>B. D. Cullity (1971), Fundamentals of magnetostriction. ''Journal of Metals'' '''1''', 323.</ref> According to IEEE: "Piezomagnetism is the linear magnetomechanical effect analogous to the linear electromechanical effect of [[piezoelectricity]]. Similarly, magnetostriction and electrostriction are analogous second-order effects. These higher-order effects can be represented as effectively first-order when variations in the system parameters are small compared with the initial values of the parameters".<ref>IEEE Std 319-1990 (1991), IEEE Standard on Magnetostrictive Materials: Piezomagnetic Nomenclature.</ref>
The piezomagnetic effect is made possible by an absence of certain symmetry elements in a crystal structure; specifically, symmetry under time reversal forbids the property.<ref>I. E. Dzialoshinskii (1958), The problem of piezomagnetism. ''Soviet Phys. JETP'' '''6''', 621.</ref>
The first experimental observation of piezomagnetism was made in 1960, in the fluorides of cobalt and manganese.<ref>A.S. Borovik-Romanov (1960), Piezomagnetism in the antiferromagnetic fluorides of cobalt and manganese. ''Soviet Phys. JETP'' '''11''', 786.</ref>
The strongest piezomagnet known is uranium dioxide, with magnetoelastic memory switching at magnetic fields near 180,000 Oe.<ref>M. Jaime et al. (2017), Piezomagnetism and magnetoelastic memory in uranium dioxide. ''Nature Communications'' '''8''', 99.</ref>

The '''''Rena'' oil spill''' occurred off the coast of [[Tauranga]] in [[New Zealand]]. The spill was caused by the [[ship grounding|grounding]] of {{MV|Rena}} on the [[Astrolabe Reef]]. The ''Rena'' was a [[container ship]] and cargo vessel owned by the Greek shipping company [[Costamare|Costamare Inc.]], through one of its subsidiary companies, and chartered by the [[Mediterranean Shipping Company]] (MSC). The spill has been described as New Zealand's worst maritime environmental disaster.<ref name=stuff3>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758195 |title='Worst maritime environmental disaster' |work=New Zealand Herald |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref>
==Sequence of events== On Wednesday, 5 October 2011, at 2:20 AM (Tuesday, 4 October 13:20 UTC) while sailing in clear weather from [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] to [[Tauranga]], at a speed of {{convert|17|kn}}, ''Rena'' [[ship grounding|ran aground]] on the Astrolabe Reef.<ref name="MNZ">{{cite web |url=http://www.maritimenz.govt.nz/news/media-releases-2011/20111005c.asp |title=Tauranga incident response update |publisher=Maritime New Zealand |date=2011-10-05 |accessdate=2011-10-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://costamare.irwebpage.com/pr100711.html |title=M/V Rena Information |publisher=Costamare Inc |date=7 October 2011 |accessdate=2011-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120720010921/http://costamare.irwebpage.com/pr100711.html |archivedate=20 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The ship was carrying 1,368 containers, eight of which contained hazardous materials, as well as 1,700 tonnes of heavy fuel oil and 200 tonnes of [[marine diesel oil]].<ref name=stuff2>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/5763630/Rena-worst-maritime-environmental-disaster |title=Rena 'worst maritime environmental disaster' |work=Stuff |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> Initially the ship [[List (watercraft)|listed]] 11 degrees to port, with the front stuck on the reef.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sail-world.com/Cruising/international/Maritime-NZ-Update:-Tue-11-Oct---Rena-rotates-through-25-degrees/89504 |title=Maritime NZ Update: Tue 11 Oct - Rena rotates through 25 degrees |work=Sail World |accessdate=13 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019175714/http://www.sail-world.com/Cruising/international/Maritime-NZ-Update:-Tue-11-Oct---Rena-rotates-through-25-degrees/89504 |archivedate=19 October 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
By Sunday, 9 October 2011, a {{convert|5|km|mi}} oil slick threatened wildlife and the area's rich fishing waters.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15230941 |title=New Zealand oil ship leak 'raises questions |work=BBC News |date=2011-10-09 |accessdate=2011-10-11}}</ref>
Oil from ''Rena'' began washing ashore at [[Mount Maunganui]] beach on 10 October 2011.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10757900 |title='Highly toxic' water at Mt Maunganui |work=New Zealand Herald |date=10 October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2011 |first1=Newstalk |last1=Zb}}</ref> Bad weather that night had caused the ship to shift further onto the reef, and the crew was evacuated.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/5763630/Stricken-ship-crew-ashore-after-mayday-call |title=Stricken ship crew ashore after mayday call |work=Stuff |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2011}}</ref><ref name=nzh1>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758195 |title=Rena crew 'terrified' by tipping |work=New Zealand Herald |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=11 October 2011}}</ref> The shifting of the ship caused further damage, resulting in a further 130 - 350 tonnes of oil leaking.<ref name=nzh1/>
Strong winds and bad weather on the night of 11 October 2011 caused the ship to list over to starboard 19 degrees; this resulted in between 30 and 70 containers being washed overboard.<ref name=stuff1>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/5770592/Containers-fall-from-grounded-ship-Rena |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130112065032/http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/5770592/Containers-fall-from-grounded-ship-Rena |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 January 2013 |title=Rena captain in court, containers overboard |work=Stuff |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011 }}</ref> None of the containers contained hazardous cargo.<ref name=stuff1 /> Containers subsequently began washing ashore on [[Motiti Island]].<ref name=stuff1 />
On the afternoon of 12 October 2011, aerial footage showed a large crack in the hull, increasing fears that the ship could break in two and sink.<ref name=tvnz1>{{cite web |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/massive-crack-rena-4460592 |title=Massive crack on Rena |publisher=TVNZ |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> It also showed a container floating in the water surrounded by smoke, suggesting that a chemical reaction was occurring.<ref name=tvnz1 />
On 13 October 2011, [[Maritime New Zealand]] ordered beaches from Mount Maunganui to Maketu Point, including the [[Maketu|Maketu Estuary]], to be closed to the public.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK1110/S00337/public-notice-beach-access-restricted.htm |title=Public notice – beach access restricted |publisher=Maritime New Zealand |date=13 October 2011 |accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> Volunteers were warned that contact with spilled oil could lead to vomiting, nausea and rashes, and local residents were urged to close their windows to limit fumes.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5776794/Cleanup-crew-warned-of-health-risks |title=Cleanup crew warned of health risks |work=Dominion-Post |author=Shane Cowlishaw |date=13 October 2011 |accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref>
Costamare Shipping, the owners of ''Rena'', apologised to the people of Tauranga, saying they were "deeply sorry" for the "disastrous event."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5776790/Deeply-sorry-for-your-situation-Renas-owner |title='Deeply sorry for your situation' - Rena's owner |publisher=Fairfax NZ |date=13 October 2011|accessdate=13 October 2011}}</ref> Although not legally obligated to do so, the charterer, Mediterranean Shipping Company, promised to help with the cleanup costs.<ref name="mschelps">{{cite web |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/MSC-will-help-foot-Rena-cleanup-bill--Joyce/tabid/419/articleID/229770/Default.aspx |title=MSC will help foot Rena cleanup bill |publisher=3 News |date=17 October 2011 | accessdate=22 October 2011}}</ref> [[File:NZ Defence Force assistance to OP Rena at the beach.jpg|thumb|[[New Zealand Army]] personnel cleaning oil from Papamoa Beach on 11 October]]
On 14 October 2011, it was reported that the ship's hull had cracked in half, and the bow and stern sections were held together only by internal structures and the reef.<ref name=stuff4>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5783705/Rena-salvage-Preparations-to-pump-oil |title=Rena salvage: Preparations to pump oil |work=Stuff |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref> Calmer weather meant that preparations could be made to pump out the remainder of the ship's oil,<ref name=stuff4/> but a change in the wind direction meant that oil was likely to spread as far east as [[Whakatane]] and [[Opotiki]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/oil-could-make-whakatane-shore-4464049 |title=Oil could make it to Whakatane shore |publisher=TVNZ |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref>
Also on 14 October 2011, the [[Filipino people|Filipino]] crew of the ''Rena'' left New Zealand "for their safety" after a racist backlash against Filipinos in Tauranga.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758929 |title=Rena crew quit NZ for their 'safety' |publisher=New Zealand Herald |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14 |first=Lincoln |last=Tan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5785635/Filipinos-fear-Rena-backlash |title=Filipinos fear Rena backlash |work=Stuff |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref>
Calm weather on 15 October 2011, allowed salvage experts to board the vessel and begin preparations to pump the remaining oil to a barge.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5789174/Groaning-creaking-Rena-unsafe-for-oil-pumping |title='Groaning, creaking' Rena unsafe for oil pumping |work=Stuff |date=2011-10-15 |accessdate=2011-10-17}}</ref> Platforms were attached to the side of the ship, and pumping began on 16 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5792006/Rena-salvage-crews-start-pumping |title=Rena salvage crews start pumping |work=Stuff |date=2011-10-16 |accessdate=2011-10-17}}</ref> By 17 October only twenty tons of oil had been removed.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10759676 |title=Rena: race to pump oil from 'dying ship' |work=New Zealand Herald |date=2011-10-17 |accessdate=2011-10-17}}</ref>
On 16 October a mine-countermeasures team aboard [[HMNZS Manawanui (A09)|HMNZS ''Manawanui'']] began hunting for spilled containers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/navy-uses-sonar-locate-containers-4467283 |title=Navy uses sonar to locate containers |publisher=TVNZ |date=2011-10-17 |accessdate=2011-10-17}}</ref>
After October, salvage efforts were focused on removing the ship's cargo before it completely broke apart.
In January 2012, the ''Rena'' completely broke in half and the stern section slipped off of the reef and eventually sank.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/gallery/2012/jan/11/newzealand-asia-pacific |title=Cargo ship Rena breaks up on New Zealand reef - in pictures |date=11 January 2012 |accessdate=13 January 2012 |location=London |work=The Guardian}}</ref> A small amount of oil and containers escaped the ship as it broke in half.
By 23 March 2012, 649 containers of cargo had been recovered and it was thought that only a few tens of tonnes of oil still remained in the ship.<ref>{{cite news|title=Fresh oil spills from Rena|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10794156|work=New Zealand Herald|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=23 March 2012}}</ref>
==Media coverage and public reactions== The incident was not immediately brought to the public eye since it took place on 5 October 2011, the same day the well-known American businessman [[Steve Jobs]] died.<ref>{{cite web|last=Cheng|first=Jacqui|title=Steve Jobs: February 24, 1955 - October 5, 2011|url=https://arstechnica.com/apple/news/2011/10/steve-jobs-february-24-1955---october-5-2011.ars|website=www.arstechnica.com|accessdate=2012-03-27}}</ref> In addition, media outlets had their hands full with the [[Occupy Wall Street Movement]] that was taking place.<ref>{{cite web|last=Forer|first=Ben|title=Occupy Wall St. Protests: Live Blog|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/Economy/occupy-wall-st-protests-live-blog/story?id=14675410|work=ABC News|accessdate=29 March 2012}}</ref> Information about the oil spill did not surface on major news websites until four days later when [[CBC News]] published an article on 9 October 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Zealand Oil Spill Cleanup Begins Amid Storm Fears|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2011/10/09/new-zealand-oil-spill.html|publisher=CBC|accessdate=29 March 2012}}</ref> British newspaper ''[[The Guardian]]'' then released a piece on the incident on 10 October 2011,<ref>{{cite news|last=Milman|first=Oliver|title=New Zealand oil spill : conservationists warn of wildlife 'tragedy'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2011/oct/10/new-zealand-oil-spill-wildlife-tragedy|work=The Guardian|accessdate=29 March 2012|location=London|date=10 October 2011}}</ref> followed by the [[BBC]] on 11 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Oil spill disaster New Zealand's 'worst in decades'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15251319|publisher=BBC|accessdate=29 March 2012}}</ref>
Residents of [[Motiti Island]] voiced their concerns over the effects the oil spill was having on their lifestyles, since they relied on water filled in tanks and seafood from the affected waters for survival. It cost islanders approximately $100 to leave the island for food or water; this expense along with the toxic water and seafood raised concern among the citizens of [[Motiti Island]] that their lives might never be the same.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rena oil spill: Thursday as it happened|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/rena-oil-spill-thursday-happened-4462546|accessdate=28 March 2012|newspaper=BBCnews}}</ref>
New Zealand environmental minister, [[Nick Smith (New Zealand politician)|Nick Smith]], said that the impact of this spill was the most significant in New Zealand history. Reporter Karen Barlow of [[Lateline]] said that it may not be the biggest ever oil spill, but it could be catastrophic for the pristine waters of the Bay of Plenty.<ref>{{cite web|last=Barlow|first=Karen|title=New Zealand faces worst ever environmental disaster|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2011/s3337406.htm|publisher=ABC|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> [[World Wildlife Fund]] spokesperson, Bob Zuur, confirmed a major loss of wildlife.<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|title=Oil spill disaster New Zealand's 'worst in decades'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-15251319|accessdate=28 March 2012|work=BBC News|date=11 October 2011}}</ref>
==Cleanup== "The cleanup for the Rena Oil spill will take time," said New Zealand scientist Dr. Norm Duke. "[[Mineral oil|Petroleum oil]] will naturally break down - but this takes time and oxygenation. So, the longer the oil remains floating at sea - the safer it becomes. And, the rougher the weather - the better also."<ref>{{cite news|last=Duke|first=Norm|title=Dr Norm Duke, Professorial Research Fellow, Mangrove Hub, James Cook University comments:|url=http://www.aussmc.org/2011/10/rapid-reaction-cleaning-up-the-rena-oil-spill-in-new-zealand-–-experts-respond/|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=10 October 2011}}</ref> <!--(the following bit needs work, and maybe relocation) When this first occurred, volunteers in the area helped out as much as possible. Soon came The NZ army and Dept. of Conservation which started to clean as well.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rena oil spill and clean-up Operation|url=http://www.demotix.com/news/870813/rena-oil-spill-and-clean-operation|accessdate=29 March 2012|date=12 October 2011}}</ref>-->
[[Maritime New Zealand]] used the oil dispersant [[Corexit|Corexit 9500]] to help in the cleanup process. Corexit is known to increase the toxicity of oil.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/environment/rena-crisis/5767822/Dispersants-worse-than-oil|title=Dispersants 'worse than oil'|work=Stuff|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> The dispersant was applied for only a week, after results proved inconclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sciencelearn.org.nz/Science-Stories/Where-Land-Meets-Sea/Cleaning-up-the-oil-spill|title=Cleaning up the oil spill|work=Sciencelearn Hub|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
==Salvage teams== * As of 2011, there were approximately 400 trained responders to oil spills in the country. [[Marine Pollution Response Service]] advised that most of the responders had received low level training, estimating that only 60 of the 400 trained have achieved high level training. The Marine Pollution Response Service suggested that a higher level of training was required in various levels of response training. Also, there was a report of insufficient development in the information and training given to this team.<ref>{{cite news|title= Review of New Zealand’s Oil Pollution Preparedness and Response Capability |url=http://www.maritimenz.govt.nz/Publications-and-forms/Environmental-protection/OPPRC-Review-February-2011.pdf }}</ref> * A salvage company named Svitzer was hired to assess the safety of contracted salvage teams on the ship and to continue to carry out salvage procedures. Matthew Watson, a spokesman for Svitzer, described the key tasks carried out by the salvage teams to be removal of oil off of the ship (specifically through a transferring process) and the collection of released containers and other waste. Salvage teams were helicoptered onto the ship, as that was advised as the safest way.<ref name="second-officer-charged" />
==Environmental impact== *The fuel on board the ''Rena'' consisted of 1,700 tonnes of heavy oil and 200 tonnes of diesel fuel.<ref>{{cite web|last=Taylor|first=Alan|title=Oil Spill Disaster on New Zealand|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/infocus/2011/10/oil-spill-disaster-on-new-zealand-shoreline/100169/|work=The Atlantic|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> It was thought that in the [[Bay of Plenty]] over a thousand tonnes of sand would need to be removed in order to get the oil out.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rena spill: Sand removal plan to get oil pollution off beaches|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758937|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=28 March 2012|author=Isaac Davidson|author2=James Ihaka |date=14 October 2011}}</ref> *Within the range of where the oil spilled the rare New Zealand spotted [[dotterel]] bird and 25 other native birds species inhabit.<ref name="Sands">{{cite web|last=Sands|first=Neil|title=New Zealand counts wildlife cost from oil spill|url=http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-10-zealand-wildlife-oil.html|publisher=Physorg|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> Attempts by local people and 36 wildlife teams/centers to help save or decontaminate the avian species were established.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hughes|first=Greg|title='Massive' oil spill clean-up underway in New Zealand|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-10-12/asia/world_asia_new-zealand-oil-spill-disaster_1_oil-spill-toxic-dispersants-cleaning-oil?_s=PM:ASIA|publisher=Cable News Network|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=13 October 2011}}</ref> Conayne from the Wildlife Rescue Center explains that a handful of fur seals had been captured to keep them out of the oil from the Rena.<ref name="Sands"/> In another attempt to save the animals, people knitted [[Penguin sweater|jumpers and sweaters]] for little blue penguins to wear. These were designed to prevent the penguins from becoming cold and prevent them ingesting oil while preening.<ref>{{cite news|title=Penguins Get Sweaters To Protect Them From New Zealand Oil Spill|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/10/21/new-zealand-penguins-oil-sweaters_n_1022661.html|website=TheHuffingtonPost.com|accessdate=28 March 2012|first=James|last=Gerken|date=21 October 2011}}</ref> One group of 49 [[little penguin]]s was successfully released back into the wild in late November 2011.<ref name="Backhouse">{{cite news|last=Backhouse|first=Matthew|title=Penguin reigns in battle for nation's hearts|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10775569|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=28 December 2011}}</ref> * Over the duration of the event, 383 oiled little blue penguins were admitted to the oiled wildlife facility. 95% of these (365 penguins) were released back to the wild with 18 admitted birds dying (thirteen required euthanasia and another five died in care). 89 dead oiled penguins were recovered through the response. Just over one quarter of these birds suffered 90-100% oiling.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.massey.ac.nz/massey/learning/departments/centres-research/wildbase/wildbase-oil-response/response/case-studies/rena-oilspill/blue-penguin-post-release.cfm|title = Blue penguins bear the brunt of the Rena oil spill|date = 2014-07-15|accessdate = 2014-08-14|website = Massey University|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> *The tragedy caused about 2,000 seabirds deaths.<ref name="Backhouse"/> An estimate of 20,000 birds are thought to be victims of the oil spill through their ecosystem and food sources being contaminated.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rena: Oil clean-up chemical worries Greenpeace|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/rena-oil-spill/news/article.cfm?c_id=1503203&objectid=10768517|work=[[New Zealand Herald]]|accessdate=28 March 2012|date=25 November 2011}}</ref> One outcome that is not yet determined is the effect on the ocean's ecosystems in the area of where the Rena spilled the oil. [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]] Rob Zuur explains "it would take years to know the full impact of the oil spill on the Bay of Plenty’s ecosystem, which also contains huge marine kelp forests and is home to a large fishing industry".<ref name="Sands"/> "Filter-feeding whales are at risk from sticky oil clinging to their baleen plates as they feed" said Al Fleming, Tauranga-based Central North Island field officer of New Zealand.<ref name="http://www.ens--newswire.com">{{cite web|title=New Zealand's Biggest Oil Spill Worsens, Hits Beache|url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/oct2011/2011-10-11-01.html|website=www.ens--newswire.com/|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> According to Fleming, the oil's effect on finfish, shellfish, crustaceans and other marine life could be disastrous.<ref name="http://www.ens--newswire.com"/> In addition, the oil will affect birds and marine mammals by ingestion, and bio-accumulation whereby the toxicity of the oil can be responsible for long or short term effects.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ma|first=Vienna|title=nterview: New Zealand's oil spills to have long term negative impacts on environment: experts|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/indepth/2011-10/12/c_131187382.htm|agency=Xinhua|accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> *Blobs of heavy oil washed up on the beach shores of [[Mount Maunganui]] and [[Papamoa]], and were expected to continue to wash up in other parts of New Zealand. The beaches affected were closed until cleanup crews arrived, and locals were instructed to keep a distance from the shore and the oil clusters.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
==Political consequences== The disaster occurred only seven weeks prior to the [[New Zealand general election, 2011|2011 general election]] (which took place on 26 November 2011) and partially affected the campaign.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/environment/news/article.cfm?c_id=39&objectid=10758891 |title=Rena oil-spill emergency winds up political leaders |work=New Zealand Herald |author=Audrey Young |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref> On 14 October it was reported that the disaster had caused a 4% drop in the governing [[New Zealand National Party|National Party]]'s polling on the ''[[iPredict]]'' [[prediction market]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/5786118/Rena-disaster-hurts-National-site |title=Rena disaster hurts National - site |website=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |date=2011-10-14 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref>
On 13 October 2011, the [[New Zealand Labour Party]] announced that it would impose a moratorium on [[Offshore drilling|deep sea drilling for oil]] if elected to power.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.3news.co.nz/Despite-Rena-disaster-Govt-still-keen-on-deep-sea-drilling/tabid/419/articleID/229430/Default.aspx |title=Rena Disaster sees Labour rush out policy to stop deep sea drilling |author=Patrick Gower |publisher=[[3 News]] |date=2011-10-13 |accessdate=2011-10-14}}</ref>
In 2012 the government announced a twelve-month environmental recovery plan for the area with an expected cost of NZ$2–3 million (US$1.6M–2.5M as of January 2012).<ref>{{cite press release|title=Environmental Recovery plan for Rena launched|publisher=New Zealand government|date=26 January 2012|url=http://beehive.govt.nz/release/environmental-recovery-plan-rena-launched|accessdate=26 January 2012}}</ref>
==Criminal charges== On 12 October 2011, the captain of ''Rena'' appeared in the Tauranga District Court charged with operating a vessel causing unnecessary danger or risk to a person or property. He was granted name suppression and remanded on [[bail]].<ref name=stuff1/> If convicted he faced a fine of up to $10,000 or up to 12 months imprisonment.<ref name=nzh2>{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758416 |title=Rena oil spill: masks could be issued |work=New Zealand Herald|date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref> The ship's second officer, who was responsible for navigation at the time of the accident, was subsequently charged and appeared in court on 13 October.<ref name="second-officer-charged">{{cite news |url= http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10758590 |title=Rena spill: Second officer charged |work=New Zealand Herald |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=12 October 2011}}</ref>
The two men, both Filipino, pleaded guilty to 11 charges between them, including attempting to pervert the course of justice (based on alleged alteration of navigational documents after the collision).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.3news.co.nz/nznews/crown-outlines-rena-case-ahead-of-sentencing-2012052511|title=Crown outlines Rena case ahead of sentencing|publisher=|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref> The sentencing for both men was scheduled for 25 May 2012.<ref>{{cite news|title=New Zealand container shipwreck captain pleads guilty|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/feb/29/new-zealand-oil-spill-guilty|accessdate=27 March 2012|newspaper=theguardian|location=London|date=29 February 2012}}</ref>
The (New Zealand) [[Transport Accident Investigation Commission]] released an interim report into the grounding on 8 March 2012. The report states only what happened but not why, and does not apportion blame. It states that ''Rena'' arrived at the port of [[Napier, New Zealand|Napier]] and began unloading cargo, but was forced to stand off in the harbour when a ship with priority booking arrived. ''Rena'' was therefore delayed 13 hours in leaving Napier. On making the run toward Tauranga, the captain was under pressure to make up time and to arrive at the port's pilot station by 3:00 am, and the ship's charts showed that a more direct course than usual had been set that took ''Rena'' toward Astrolabe Reef. An intermittent radar echo first noticed at 2:05 am was ignored when nothing was seen through binoculars, and at 2:14 ''Rena'' struck the reef.<ref>http://www.taic.org.nz/ReportsandSafetyRecs/MarineReports/Renasgroundingdetailinaccidentreport/tabid/244/language/en-US/Default.aspx</ref><ref>Transport Accident Investigation Commission - full report (first page is blank) http://www.taic.org.nz/LinkClick.aspx?fileticket=1O0%2bnlsp%2fBQ%3d&tabid=87&language=en-US</ref>
On 25 May 2012, the captain and navigation officer appeared in Tauranga District Court for sentencing. Each was sentenced to 7 months imprisonment.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10808468|title=Rena captain jailed for 7 months|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=14 May 2015}}</ref>
==Treaty of Waitangi case== Three Bay of Plenty iwi groups have launched a breach of the Treaty of Waitangi case against the Crown. Their key concern is that they were not adequately consulted in regard to the Crown agreeing to receive $10 million as compensation for the remains of the wreck not being removed. The government agreed to the compensation payment when a storm caused the remains of the wreck to fall off the reef onto the seabed and marine demolition experts said it was too dangerous to remove it.<ref>{{cite news |title='Remove Rena cancer' - iwi |first=Elton |last=Smallman |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/10216680/Remove-Rena-cancer-Iwi |newspaper=Waikato Times |date=1 July 2014 |accessdate=9 July 2014}}</ref>
==Past spills== The second most extreme oil spill New Zealand has experienced since 1990 was the Jody F. Millennium log ship incident.<ref name="newzealand.govt.nz">{{cite web|title=Major oil spills around New Zealand|url=http://www.maritimenz.govt.nz/Environmental/Responding-to-spills-and-pollution/Past-spill-responses/Past-spill-responses.asp |publisher=newzealand.govt.nz |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> The ship broke free from several of her moorings in [[Gisborne, New Zealand|Gisborne]] Harbour due to huge swells on Wednesday 6 February 2002.<ref name="newzealand.govt.nz"/> Tugboats attempted to bring the ship alongside the wharf, but it was then decided to take the ship to sea.<ref name="newzealand.govt.nz"/> A big swell hit the ship which then grounded on the beach.<ref name="newzealand.govt.nz"/> An estimated 25 tonnes of fuel oil leaked out of the ship.<ref name="newzealand.govt.nz"/>

A '''solar bus''' or '''solar-charged bus''' is a [[bus]] which is powered exclusively or mainly by [[solar energy]]. A solar-powered bus service is referred to as a '''solar bus service'''. The use of the term "solar bus" normally implies that solar energy is used not only for powering electric equipment on the bus, but also for the [[propulsion]] of the vehicle.
Existing solar buses are [[battery electric bus]]es or (in the case of hybrid solar buses) [[hybrid bus]]es equipped with [[Electric-vehicle battery|batteries]] which are recharged from solar (or other) power sources; a launch of a solar bus service often goes hand in hand with investments for large-scale installations of stationary [[solar panel]]s with [[photovoltaic cell]]s. Similarly as other [[solar vehicle]]s, many solar buses have photovoltaic cells contained in [[solar panel]]s on the vehicle's roof which convert the [[sun]]'s energy directly into [[electric energy]] to be used by the engine.
The introduction of solar buses and other [[green vehicle]]s for purposes of [[public transport]] forms a part of [[sustainable transport]] schemes.
== About ==
=== Solar-only and solar-electric bus services === The distinction between a solar-only electric bus and an electro-solar bus is fluid, as the distinction depends on the actual usage: whether the bus is recharged from solar or other power sources.
Solar-only bus services involve recharging the bus from solar energy, usually from solar panel-covered [[bus station]] [[Canopy (building)|canopies]]. The concept is similar to that of [[solar parking plot]] for cars and bicycles, where vehicles can re-charge while parked. The need for recharging poses constraints on the run and standstill times of the bus. The implementation of a solar bus service benefits from an optimization of over-all requirements for the specific bus service.<ref name="ait-2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.ait.ac.at/fileadmin/cmc/downloads/Magazine/Neu/Tomorrow_Today_Dezember_2011_en.pdf |pages=22–25 |title=The right drive for e-mobility |publisher= |date=December 2011 |accessdate=2013-01-12}}</ref>
Electro-solar buses are powered additionally from electric power [[Electric power transmission|transmitted]] from power plants; hybrid solar buses may be equipped with [[hybrid engine]]s.
=== Commercially available shuttle buses === Open air low-speed electric shuttle sightseeing buses equipped with a solar panel-covered roof are produced in series and are commercially available. According to the producers, the solar panels save energy and prolong the battery life cycle.
== Use ==
=== Australia === The '''Tindo''' solar battery-charged bus ("Tindo", [[Kaurna language|Kaurna]] word for ''sun'') is an experimental [[battery electric vehicle]] that operates in [[Adelaide|Adelaide, Australia]]. It is the world's first solar bus, operating since 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mnn.com/green-tech/transportation/photos/7-modern-solar-powered-vehicles/tindo-solar-bus |title=7 modern solar-powered vehicles: Tindo Solar Bus | MNN - Mother Nature Network |publisher=MNN |date= |accessdate=2013-09-18}}</ref> It uses 100% solar power, is equipped with a [[Regenerative brake|regenerative braking system]] and air conditioning and can carry up to 40 persons,<ref>{{cite news|first1=Kien |last1=To |first2=John E. |last2=Fernández |title=Alternative urban technologies demonstration projects for innovative cities |work=Third International Engineering Systems Symposium, CESUN 2012, Delft University of Technology |date=18–20 June 2012 }}</ref> 25 of whom are seated. The bus itself is not equipped with solar panels. It receives electric power from a [[photovoltaics|photovoltaic]] system on Adelaide's central [[bus station]]. Hailed as the world's first bus service powered exclusively by solar power, the bus service connects Adelaide City and North Adelaide as part of Adelaide City's sustainable transport agenda. The Tindo is part of the 98A and 98C bus service (until recently known as the Adelaide Connector) which is offered as [[free public transport]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ecogeek.org/content/view/1245/ |title=All-Electric, Solar-Powered, Free Bus!!! |publisher=Ecogeek.org |date=2007-12-27 |accessdate=2013-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090908184215/http://www.ecogeek.org/content/view/1245/ |archivedate=2009-09-08 |df= }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://yoursay.adelaidecitycouncil.com/city-connector-bus |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222075212/http://yoursay.adelaidecitycouncil.com/city-connector-bus |archivedate=2015-12-22 |df= }}</ref>
=== China === Within the Chinese government's program for clean transport sector, [[China]]'s first solar hybrid buses were put in operation in July 2012 in the city of [[Qiqihar]]. Its engine is powered by [[lithium-ion battery|lithium-ion batteries]] which are fed by solar panels installed on the bus roof. It is claimed that each bus consumes 0.6 to 0.7 kilowatt-hours of electricity per kilometer and can transport up to 100 persons, and that the use of solar panels prolongs the batteries' lifetime by 35 percent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://naftcenews.wvu.edu/naftc_enews/2012/9/7/china-reveals-new-solar-buses |title=China Reveals New Solar Buses |publisher=[[West Virginia University]] |date=2012-09-07 |accessdate=2013-01-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009112858/http://naftcenews.wvu.edu/naftc_enews/2012/9/7/china-reveals-new-solar-buses |archivedate=2015-10-09 |df= }}</ref>
=== Europe === Austria's first solar-powered bus was put in operation in the village of [[Perchtoldsdorf]]. Its [[powertrain]], operating strategy, and [[design specification]] were specifically optimized in view of its planned regular service routes. It has been in trial operation since autumn 2011.<ref name="ait-2013"/>
The [[Hybrid electric bus#Tribrid Bus|tribrid bus]] is a [[hybrid electric bus]] developed by the [[University of Glamorgan]], [[Wales]], for use as student transport between the University’s different campuses. It is powered by [[hydrogen fuel]] or [[solar cell]]s, batteries and [[ultracapacitor]]s.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Green 'tribrid' minibus unveiled|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/wales/7436908.stm |work=BBC |date=2008-06-05 |accessdate=2013-01-12}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Launch of Europe's First Tribrid Green Minibus |url=http://news.glam.ac.uk/news/en/2008/may/30/launch-europes-first-tibrid-green-minibus/ |work= |date=2008-05-30 |accessdate=2013-01-12}}</ref>
=== UK ===
The first Solar Bus in the UK launched in [[Brighton]] April 2017. Following a marathon six week effort from hundreds of local people, [[The Big Lemon]] and [[Brighton Energy Coop]]'s joint Solar Bus project has won funding from the M&S Community Energy Fund to cover the roof of [[The Big Lemon]]’s bus depot in solar panels to power the new electric buses on clean green renewable energy. The bus was named by one of the Solar Roof partners, Viper IT Solutions and is called "Om Shanti".
The 120 solar panels will generate 30,000kW of electricity – the equivalent of 1.8 million boiled kettles. With no emissions, the Solar Buses will reduce noxious gases in some of Brighton and Hove’s most polluted areas and will power the 52 route between Woodingdean and [[Brighton]] on 100% renewable energy.
The Solar Bus project was one of 199 different applications to the scheme, 125 of which were shortlisted. These were put to public vote for six weeks during September and October and the voting process also included the option to donate to the project via the Crowdfunding platform.
The Solar Bus project was one of 19 regional winners, with 1549 votes, 170 pledges, and a total of £13,325 raised through crowdfunding, almost half the total amount of £28,798 raised through the scheme nationally. The project will benefit from £12,500 funding from M&S Energy which, together with the £13,325 crowdfunding donations will fund the solar array on the roof of the bus depot.
<ref>https://thebiglemon.com/2016/11/01/the-big-lemon-wins-funding-for-solar-bus-project-from-ms-energy-fund/</ref>
===Uganda=== The Kayoola Solar Bus is a 35-seater electric solar bus with zero tailpipe emissions, a range of 80 km, with latent range extension from the real-time charging enabled by the roof mounted solar panels. The development of the Kayoola Solar Bus Concept represents the commitment of the Kiira Motors Project to championing the progressive development of local capacity for Vehicle Technology Innovation, a key ingredient for institutionalizing a sustainable Vehicle Manufacturing Industry in Uganda. <ref>http://edition.cnn.com/2016/02/15/africa/africa-solar-bus-kiira-uganda/index.html?iid=ob_lockedrail_topeditorial&iref=obnetwork</ref><ref>http://kiiramotors.com/kayoola.pdf</ref>
===United States=== The Solar Buzz is a 14-seater US Electricar bus, made in 1994, that has been repurposed as the world's first truly solar bus in [[Truth or Consequences, New Mexico]] in 2011. The Buzz has 2 KW in homemade solar panels on the roof, 40 golf cart batteries, 2 electric motors, and has no tailpipe. The power required to go one mile is the same as the power required to make a pot of coffee: around 700 Wh. The Solar Buzz is an IntraCity bus approved by the state Public Regulation Commission (#56817) in 2015 and is a commercial daytime private shuttle service with a US$3 Fare, operated by Hot Springs Transit, LLC. <ref>http://krqe.com/2016/01/28/new-mexico-woman-invents-states-first-solar-powered-bus/</ref> Hot Springs Transit provides transit service to the 6100 person population of Truth or Consequences.
== Other forms of green bus transport ==
=== Non-solar powered engines === Solar panels are also used for powering electronic devices of the bus such as heating and air conditioning, even in buses with non-solar-powered engine. In the US, such buses are advertised to meet [[anti-idling]] regulations in several states.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Bauer introduces solar bus powering system at BusCon |url=http://www.metro-magazine.com/news/story/2010/10/gary-bauer-introduces-solar-bus-powering-system-at-buscon.aspx |work=metro magazine |date=2010-10-06 |accessdate=2013-01-12}}</ref>
Refitting existing non-existing vehicles with photovoltaic panels that feed the original battery with additional electric power has been shown to have the potential for making a substantial contribution to [[CO2 emission]] mitigation and to the [[pollution prevention|reduction of pollution]].<ref name="Donno-2012">{{cite news |first1=Monica |last1=Donno |first2=Aleck |last2=Ferrari |first3=Annalisa |last3=Scarpelli |first4=Pietro |last4=Perlo |first5=Alberto |last5=Bocca |title=Mechatronic system for energy efficiency in bus transport |url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=6176493&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D6176493 |work=Design, Automation & Test in Europe Conference & Exhibition, 2012 |pages=342–343 |date=12–16 March 2012 |accessdate=2013-01-12}}</ref> The thus transformed buses are however not solar buses in the strict sense of the word, as they do not use solar energy for propulsion. The use of buses in public transport implies frequent stops with the opening and closing of doors, which influence the way the energy of the battery is used.<ref name="Donno-2012"/>
=== Renewable energy powered === In principle also [[trolleybus]]es or other non-autonomous electric buses or alternately powered buses such as [[fuel cell bus]]es or [[dual-mode bus]]es could be used for solar bus services, provided the origin of all or most of the energy used for propulsing the bus would be solar energy. In practice however such systems also draw on other sources of energy, at least also other [[renewable energy]] sources such as [[wind energy]]. An example is that the city of [[Hamburg]], Germany, received the 2011 [[European Green Capital Award]] for, among others, its fuel cell bus service that is claimed to be the world's largest hydrogen-powered bus fleet and is intended to use hydrogen generated from solar and wind energy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/environment/europeangreencapital/wp-content/uploads/2011/04/Hamburg_DE_LowResolution_DE-new1.pdf |page=8 |title=Hamburg, Preisträger 2011, |publisher=[[European Commission]] |date= |language=German |accessdate=2013-01-13}}, {{DOI|10.2779/78216}}, {{ISBN|978-92-79-21368-7}}</ref>
